Here, he's seen in front of a mural he painted. SA LIFE: Andy Benavides is an artist who has painted a mural that will be a permanent part of the museum. The monochromatic mural is an homage to Pedro Teran, the artist who did the blacklight mural at the Alameda Theater. Helen L. Montoya/Staff

San Antonio knows tacos, we have been doing it for a while, and while we appreciate Austin's enthusiasm for throwing anything on a tortilla, we may have to create a separate category for such creations -- like wrap.
Photo: Cynthia Esparza, For The San Antonio Express-News 1. This is a taco : simple ingredients with a beautiful combination... Image 7 of 21 2. Hipsters: Austin is full of them, but they are migrating to San Antonio at a pace that, while slow, is still cause for concern.
2. Hipsters: Austin is full of them, but they are migrating to San... Image 8 of 21 3. Spurs: Austin is home to the Spurs' D-League squad, who are all trying to make it to the big show down the road in San Antonio.
Photo: San Antonio Express-News 3. Spurs: Austin is home to the Spurs' D-League squad, who are all... Image 9 of 21 4. FIESTA! While many local Austinites leave town and rent out their places faced with the SXSW and ACL crowds, San Antonio businesses shut down and families from all over the city come out to party for Fiesta.
Photo: By Yvonne Zamora, For MySA.com 4. FIESTA! While many local Austinites leave town and rent out... Image 10 of 21 5. Diversity: According to the latest Census data available.
San Antonio: 26% White, 63% Hispanic or Latino, 7% African American, 2% Asian Austin: 48% white, 35% Hispanic or Latino, 8% African American, 6% Asian
Photo: J. MICHAEL SHORT, FOR THE EXPRESS-NEWS 5. Diversity: According to the latest Census data available.
San... Image 11 of 21 6. Famous actors: While Austin's famous crowd usually make a scene anywhere they go, San Antonio's famous crowd, of which Tommy Lee Jones is a part, slides in to enjoy a game or meal and then slides out without much fuss.
Photo: Eric Gay, Associated Press 6. Famous actors: While Austin's famous crowd usually make a scene... Image 12 of 21 7. Traffic: We are not pretending that San Antonio doesn't have traffic, but Austin basically has two roads that go in to and out of town and they are clogged save for a few hours of the day. San Antonio gets the edge with more ways to get around any congestion.

Photo: Courtesy Arcadia Publishing 12. History: Originally founded in 1718 as San Antonio de Bexar,... Image 18 of 21 13. Bats: The Bracken Bat Cave, just north of San Antonio, is the summer home of the world's largest bat colony. While Austin's Congress Street Bridge bat exodus is nice to see, it just doesn't come close to Bracken.
Photo: Photos By Marvin Pfeiffer / Northeast Herald 13. Bats: The Bracken Bat Cave, just north of San Antonio, is the... Image 19 of 21 14. Photo: Lauren Victoria Burke, Associated Press 14. Julián Castro: The rising political star and former San... Image 20 of 21 15. Gentrification: While San Antonio does have gentrification in parts of the city it is nothing compared to what has happened to Austin. One of the casualties of the development wave: Conjunto clubs on the East Side of Austin.
Photo: Helen L. Montoya, San Antonio Express-News 15. Gentrification: While San Antonio does have gentrification in... Image 21 of 21 San Antonio-Austin rivalry now a movie! 1 / 21 Back to Gallery SAN ANTONIO -- That age-old rivalry that seems to be heating up again of late -- Austin vs. San Antonio -- has inspired a thought-provoking feature film.
Best of all, the budding filmmaker, Noi Mahoney, is inviting the public to a free screening Saturday at a small San Antonio theater.
"Austin vs. San Antonio" will bow here at 3:30 p.m. Saturday at SAY Sí's Black Box Theatre, 1518 S. Alamo St.
Space is limited, so arrive early; seating is on a first-come, first-served basis.
Something tells me the cheering section for the Alamo City portion of the documentary will dominate -- particularly when talk of the Spurs comes up.
Actually, the love for San Antonio's NBA team is one of the things that both cities have in common.
"I found out while making the movie that there also are a lot of Spurs fans in Austin," Mahoney said.
He describes his film, which runs a little more than an hour and is divided into two sections --- San Antonio and Austin -- as "a fun, colorful scrapbook of information and recollections."
Photographs and footage throughout the doc highlight the beauty and striking looks of both cities. It features 27 voices from a wide age range. These include artists, writers, restaurateurs, actors, musicians, public officials and more from both Austin and San Antonio.
Bexar County Judge Nelson Wolff , a former San Antonio mayor, says he's proud of the close relationship enjoyed by San Antonio and Mexico.
"We're an international city," Wolff says. "We reflect the incoming demographics across the United States. We're very much a Mexican city, when you look at the United States, we're closer to Mexico, friendship wise, economics wise, relatives, friends. than any other city in the United States."
Former Austin Chronicle music writer Margaret Moser, who grew up in San Antonio but moved to Austin in 1973, opines: "Austin defines itself on music, politics and football."
Jim Beal Jr, who wrote about music for the San Antonio Express-News for years, says: "One of the misconceptions about san Antonio is it's strictly a heavy metal town. S.A. started being a vital jazz town in the 1920s. ... It's part of the birthplace of conjunto music and Tejano music."
Nikki Young, a San Antonio-based actress and producer, speaks of the rich history of film production in San Antonio, starting with "Wings," the 1927 movie filmed here that won the award for Outstanding Picture at the first Academy Awards. "(San Antonio) was the original Hollywood," she said. "Unfortunately, due to whatever multiple reasons -- there wasn't enough support, economic support in the community -- (film production) fled.
"Austin decided to take ownership," she added. "They decided they wanted to be the film capital of the state. So we didn't claim it. We lost it. They got it."
Andy Benavides, local artist and activist, calls San Antonio "the land of mañana."
"Everybody's so laid back; it moves at a different pace," he says. "You can work hard and also find that time to just stop."
S.A. artist Aaron Forland credits our NBA team with giving San Antonio the oomph it craved.
"I always felt the Spurs' championships gave the city the boost of self-confidence that it sorely needed," Forland says.
He and fellow Alamo City artist Justin Parr were responsible for the slogan "Keep San Antonio Lame" in 2003, a tongue-in-cheek response to "Keep Austin Weird."
The response here was surprisingly very positive, they recall.
What are some of the pluses of each city that Mahoney took away from his two years of filming "Austin vs. San Antonio"?
"People are less pretentious in San Antonio," the Holmes High graduate and UT Austin alumnus said in a phone chat. "Austin has that cooler-than-everybody-else mentality. The people there seem ruled more by fads. Everything has to be hip and cool."
In San Antonio, by contrast, "you can wear your flip-flops and T-shirt and no one will give you a second look."
In Austin's positive column, however, he said: "You can go there and reinvent yourself. ... You have the feeling you can be more creative there as long as you work hard enough at it."
Best conclusion from his research? "It's a very exciting time to live in both San Antonio and Austin. It's cool that we have these two cities that are so close together that are so different and with such unique culture, yet they somehow complement each other."
